qas.question: In Czech, what are loanwords from other languages associated with?
What word roots in the 19th century were rejected in favor of words with more common Slavic roots?
How does one say the word "music" in Czech?
What Czech word did the English "robot" derive from?
What is the meaning of the Czech word "robota"?
What were older Latin loanwords considered?
What kind of culture are words borrowed from Russia associated with?

plausible_answers.text: those based on older Czech words and common Slavic roots

qas.question: What were words with Russian roots rejected for in the nineteenth century?
What Russian word has the English robot been borrowed from?
What language has used borrowed words from Russian?

context: Although older German loanwords were <b5_0>colloquial<b5_0/>, recent borrowings from other languages are associated with <a0_0><b6_0>high culture<b6_0/><a0_0/>. During the nineteenth century, words with <a1_0>Greek and Latin<a1_0/> roots were rejected in favor of <b7_0>those based on older Czech words and common Slavic roots<b7_0/>; "music" is muzyka in Polish and музыка (muzyka) in Russian, but in Czech it is <a2_0>hudba<a2_0/>. Some Czech words have been borrowed as loanwords into <b9_0>English<b9_0/> and other languages—for example, robot (from <a3_0><b8_0>robota<b8_0/><a3_0/>, "<a4_0>labor<a4_0/>") and polka (from polka, "Polish woman" or from "půlka" "half").
